newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Forum sees demise of Asian stock trading floors.
newsitem.headline: Forum sees demise of Asian stock trading floors.

text.p: Stock exchange trading floors will eventually disappear in Asia, giving way to electronic trading systems, experts told a World Economic Forum meeting on Wednesday.

"Eventually there won't be any floor for a lot of stock exchanges in Asia, including Hong Kong," Edgar Cheng, chairman of the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong, told delegates at the three-day Europe-East Asia Economic Summit.
Cheng's comments followed a call by Peregrine Investments Holdings chairman Philip Tose, directed particularly at the Hong Kong stock exchange, for screen-based systems to replace floor trading.
"To me stock exchange floors are dinosaurs," said Tose. "We sit in an electronic age."
He said there was no reason why members of the Hong Kong stock exchange who have offices overseas should not have 24-hour access to a trading system linked to the exchange.

The Stock Exchange of Hong Kong introduced a second terminal system in January, allowing brokers to trade from their offices. Cheng said transactions through those terminals currently accounted for almost 50 percent of trading volume.
